notesStmt.note:
Ḥayim bar Yaʿaḳov Raʿagi: inscribed with his name (folios 307v, 311r, 311v); acrostic of Yaʿaḳov, 15th century (folio 230r). Meʾir bar Meʾir : inscribed with his name, 15th century (folios 307v, 311v). Shemuʾel bar Meʾir : inscribed with his name, 15th century (folio 310v); acquisition note by the same hand (folio 311r ). Meʾir Shemuʾel: inscribed with his name, 15th century (folio 4r). Meʾir: inscription in Hebrew: 'I am Meʾir', 15th century (folio 308v).
Humfrey Wanley (b. 1672, d. 1726), Old English scholar and librarian: inscribed with his name: 'Liber Humfredi Wanley' (folio 1r ) (). Illegible Hebrew inscriptions (folio 4r). On the inner sides of the cover there is a leaf pasted in, belonging to what appears to have been a Latin Law Dictionary of c16th century.
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: Pentateuch with Rashi's commentary and Targum Onḳelos; the Five Scrolls; the Hafṭarot; Job with Rashi's commentary and Megilat Antiochus. Aka 'Abraham's Pentateuch and Rashi'.

collation.p: 39 quires: i-xxi8 (folios 4-171), xxii6 (folios 172-177), xxiii-xxvi8 (folios 178-209), xxvii10 (folios 210-219), xxviii-xxix8 (folios 220-235), xxx6 (folios 236-241), xxxi-xxxv8 (folios 242-281), xxxvi6 (folios 282-287), xxxvii10-1 (folios 288-296), xxxviii8 (folios 297-304), xxxix8-1 (folios 305-311). No catchwords.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Ashkenazi square and semi-cursive script, partially punctuated. Avraham ben Yitsḥaḳ: inscribed with his name in two colophons and an additional scribal formula: 'Grow stronger and let us grow stronger. May no harm befall on Abraham [ben ha-ḳadosh rabi Yitsḥaḳ] the copyist not today and not ever until the donkey ascends the ladder to the heavens about which our father Yaʿaḳov had dreamed' [English translation], 14th century (219r, 288r, 307r); the name Avram and Avraham is decorated several times, (e.g. 14r, 21r, 141v, 186r, 307r). Yaʿaḳov: inscribed with his name on folio 230r: may the owner of the book have eternal life for volunteering to write the missing pages. It appears that Yaʿaḳov acquired the Pentateuch with a few of its pages missing and he himself filled in the missing gaps.

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
